description: Purification-Based Methods (also called Virtual Distillation) exploit the fact that noise turns a pure quantum state into a mixed state. By preparing multiple independent copies of the noisy state and measuring collective observables, the contribution of the dominant eigenvector of the density matrix is amplified exponentially.

The key insight is that for \(M\) copies of a noisy state \(\rho\), the quantity \(\text{Tr}[O \rho^M] / \text{Tr}[\rho^M]\) converges to the expectation value with respect to the dominant eigenvector as \(M\) grows. This is measured by applying a cyclic shift (derangement) operator across the \(M\) copies.

Proposed independently by Huggins et al. and Koczor in 2021, these methods require \(M\) copies of the quantum state but no noise model or classical simulation. The trade-off is hardware cost (\(M\times\) qubits and entangling measurements) versus exponential bias suppression.
how_it_works: Prepare \(M\) independent copies of the noisy state \(\rho\) on \(M \times n\) qubits.
Apply a cyclic shift operator \(S\) that permutes the \(M\) copies: \(S |\psi_1\rangle|\psi_2\rangle \cdots |\psi_M\rangle = |\psi_M\rangle|\psi_1\rangle \cdots |\psi_{M-1}\rangle\).
Measure the observable \(O \otimes S\) across all copies. This effectively computes \(\text{Tr}[O \rho^M]\).
Normalize by \(\text{Tr}[\rho^M]\) (measured separately or simultaneously) to obtain the purified estimate: \(\langle O \rangle_{\text{purified}} = \text{Tr}[O \rho^M] / \text{Tr}[\rho^M]\).

key_equations.label: Bias suppression
key_equations.latex: \text{Bias} = O\!\left(\left(\frac{\lambda_2}{\lambda_1}\right)^M\right), \quad \lambda_1 > \lambda_2 \text{ are the two largest eigenvalues of } \rho

bias_variance.notes: Bias is suppressed exponentially in M (number of copies). Overhead comes from requiring M copies of the state and entangling measurements. Variance is moderate since the estimator involves a ratio.

advantages: No noise model required â€” purely based on state properties
Bias suppressed exponentially in number of copies \(M\)
Applicable to any quantum computation, not circuit-specific
Can use classical shadows instead of full entangling measurements
disadvantages: Entangling measurements across copies are experimentally challenging
Variance of the ratio estimator can be large when \(\text{Tr}[\rho^M]\) is small
Limited to expectation values (not full state reconstruction)
use_cases: Near-term devices with enough qubits to spare for multiple copies
Variational algorithms where bias is the dominant error source
Platforms with native multi-qubit entangling measurements (e.g., trapped ions)
Combined with classical shadows for efficient observable estimation
